Comment: Because why would they spend healthcare money on sick and/or disabled people?  (Yes, I've heard the explanation that if you're *really* disabled, then you'll have disability exemptions. Never mind people who aren't abled enough to get through the bureaucracy. Or are disabled in ways the system can't handle. Or have chronic illnesses which overwork will worsen. Or the cruelty of the asset limits, the anti-marriage rules, etc.)

Comment: Congratulations, Utah maga! It's what they wanted.   https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2024-elections/utah-president-results  In FY 2024, Utah's Medicaid program, with a total cost of $5.3 billion, saw the federal government cover $3.6 billion (68%). Medicaid enrollment increased by 58% between April 2020 and April 2023, rising from 330,995 to 522,487. The uninsured rate for Utah adults aged 19-64 decreased from 12.2% in 2019 to 10.0% in 2023, with the largest declines among those below the poverty level.  Here's a more detailed breakdown: Federal Funding: The federal government contributes significantly to Utah's Medicaid costs, covering approximately 68% of the total.
